Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: There are ______ times the amount of livestock as there are people on the plant
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: If all meat were to be suddenly removed from our shelves, what would be the estimated reduction in food-related greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to dietitians, what type of diet is considered to contain all the necessary nutrients for a healthy life? Options: A. A diet rich in meat and fish, B. A diet consisting mainly of fruits, vegetables, and legumes, C. A diet high in dairy products, D. A diet with a balance of meat, fish, and dairy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the initial effect on produce costs when the demand for fruits, vegetables, and legumes increases due to a lack of meat? Options: A. Costs decrease, B. Costs remain the same, C. Costs increase moderately, D. Costs soar Correct Option: D
Question 4: Which region is mentioned as having difficulty growing vegetables due to its harsh environment? Options: A. Pacific Northwest of the United States, B. Mongolia, C. Amazon rainforest, D. Africa Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the result of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Many households gain income from new industries, B. Many households are left scrambling for income, C. The economy remains unaffected, D. The country becomes more prosperous Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the benefit of shifting from meat production to agricultural crops? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Higher risk of respiratory diseases, C. Workers and neighboring communities are less susceptible to respiratory diseases, D. Higher production costs Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the outcome of the increased demand for crop agriculture? Options: A. Prices increase, B. Prices remain the same, C. Prices come down, D. The demand for meat increases Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the benefits of no longer consuming meat, particularly red meat? Options: A. An increase in heart disease and cancer, B. A decrease in global biodiversity, C. Millions of deaths are avoided every year due to lower rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions, D. The risk of respiratory diseases increases Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect on global biodiversity when the pressures from agriculture subside? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It rises, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can tell you that the ground truth MCQ is related to the beginning of the transcript, which discusses the number of livestock compared to people.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, I would say Question 10, but it's not a good match because the question intent and options are different.

A better approach would be to generate new MCQs that are more closely related to the ground truth MCQ. 

That being said, if I really had to choose from the existing generated MCQs, I would say that none of them are a good match, but if I had to pick one, I would say -1 (to denote that there isn't a good match) or "Not Available" to be more clear.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A meat-free diet requires less land and water than a meat-filled diet.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: If all meat were to be suddenly removed from our shelves, what would be the estimated reduction in food-related greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to dietitians, what type of diet is considered to contain all the necessary nutrients for a healthy life? Options: A. A diet rich in meat and fish, B. A diet consisting mainly of fruits, vegetables, and legumes, C. A diet high in dairy products, D. A diet with a balance of meat, fish, and dairy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the initial effect on produce costs when the demand for fruits, vegetables, and legumes increases due to a lack of meat? Options: A. Costs decrease, B. Costs remain the same, C. Costs increase moderately, D. Costs soar Correct Option: D
Question 4: Which region is mentioned as having difficulty growing vegetables due to its harsh environment? Options: A. Pacific Northwest of the United States, B. Mongolia, C. Amazon rainforest, D. Africa Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the result of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Many households gain income from new industries, B. Many households are left scrambling for income, C. The economy remains unaffected, D. The country becomes more prosperous Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the benefit of shifting from meat production to agricultural crops? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Higher risk of respiratory diseases, C. Workers and neighboring communities are less susceptible to respiratory diseases, D. Higher production costs Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the outcome of the increased demand for crop agriculture? Options: A. Prices increase, B. Prices remain the same, C. Prices come down, D. The demand for meat increases Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the benefits of no longer consuming meat, particularly red meat? Options: A. An increase in heart disease and cancer, B. A decrease in global biodiversity, C. Millions of deaths are avoided every year due to lower rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions, D. The risk of respiratory diseases increases Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect on global biodiversity when the pressures from agriculture subside? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It rises, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, the closest match can be inferred from the information presented in the transcript and other generated MCQs.

The ground truth MCQ states that a meat-free diet requires less land and water than a meat-filled diet. This information is mentioned in the transcript: "All things considered, our new diets require less land and water."

Although there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, Question 7 mentions a related outcome of the increased demand for crop agriculture, which is a consequence of shifting away from meat consumption. However, it does not directly address the issue of land and water usage.

Given the available options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose the one that is closest in terms of content and intent, I would suggest Question 7 as a very loose match, but with the understanding that it does not directly address the ground truth MCQ's focus on land and water usage.

Index of the closest generated MCQ: 7 (with the caveat that it's not a direct match)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops

from overfishing. Throughout history,

to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning

with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a benefit of transitioning less or no meat?
Options: A. Less disease, B. Less cost, C. Increase health and life expectancy, D. More biodiversity, E. Higher crop yields, F. Oceans species rebound from overfishing, G. Lower greenhouse gas emissions, H. All of the above
Correct Option: None

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: If all meat were to be suddenly removed from our shelves, what would be the estimated reduction in food-related greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to dietitians, what type of diet is considered to contain all the necessary nutrients for a healthy life? Options: A. A diet rich in meat and fish, B. A diet consisting mainly of fruits, vegetables, and legumes, C. A diet high in dairy products, D. A diet with a balance of meat, fish, and dairy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the initial effect on produce costs when the demand for fruits, vegetables, and legumes increases due to a lack of meat? Options: A. Costs decrease, B. Costs remain the same, C. Costs increase moderately, D. Costs soar Correct Option: D

Question 5: What is the result of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Many households gain income from new industries, B. Many households are left scrambling for income, C. The economy remains unaffected, D. The country becomes more prosperous Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the benefit of shifting from meat production to agricultural crops? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Higher risk of respiratory diseases, C. Workers and neighboring communities are less susceptible to respiratory diseases, D. Higher production costs Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the outcome of the increased demand for crop agriculture? Options: A. Prices increase, B. Prices remain the same, C. Prices come down, D. The demand for meat increases Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the benefits of no longer consuming meat, particularly red meat? Options: A. An increase in heart disease and cancer, B. A decrease in global biodiversity, C. Millions of deaths are avoided every year due to lower rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions, D. The risk of respiratory diseases increases Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect on global biodiversity when the pressures from agriculture subside? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It rises, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that partially matches the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the benefits of transitioning to less or no meat, and the correct answer is "All of the above" (although it's not explicitly stated). Among the generated MCQs, Question 8 is the closest match, as it mentions one of the benefits of no longer consuming meat (particularly red meat).

However, a closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that Question 8 is not the best match. Instead, I would recommend Question 8 as a partial match, but I must consider other questions as well.

Upon re-examining the generated MCQs, I noticed that Questions 1, 3, 6, 7, 8, and 9 all mention benefits or consequences of a meatless world, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ. While none of these questions perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, they collectively cover some of the benefits mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose one generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 8. However, I must emphasize that it's not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—

years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas

and key nutrients from the approximately

fed antibiotics. As the years pass,

of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Beef and dairy production are responsible for more than ___ of all food based emissions, while providing about ___ of the world's nutrients.
Options: A. 30%, 1%, B. 40%, 4%, C. 50%, 8%, D. 60%, 18%
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: If all meat were to be suddenly removed from our shelves, what would be the estimated reduction in food-related greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to dietitians, what type of diet is considered to contain all the necessary nutrients for a healthy life? Options: A. A diet rich in meat and fish, B. A diet consisting mainly of fruits, vegetables, and legumes, C. A diet high in dairy products, D. A diet with a balance of meat, fish, and dairy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the initial effect on produce costs when the demand for fruits, vegetables, and legumes increases due to a lack of meat? Options: A. Costs decrease, B. Costs remain the same, C. Costs increase moderately, D. Costs soar Correct Option: D

Question 5: What is the result of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Many households gain income from new industries, B. Many households are left scrambling for income, C. The economy remains unaffected, D. The country becomes more prosperous Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the benefit of shifting from meat production to agricultural crops? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Higher risk of respiratory diseases, C. Workers and neighboring communities are less susceptible to respiratory diseases, D. Higher production costs Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the outcome of the increased demand for crop agriculture? Options: A. Prices increase, B. Prices remain the same, C. Prices come down, D. The demand for meat increases Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the benefits of no longer consuming meat, particularly red meat? Options: A. An increase in heart disease and cancer, B. A decrease in global biodiversity, C. Millions of deaths are avoided every year due to lower rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions, D. The risk of respiratory diseases increases Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect on global biodiversity when the pressures from agriculture subside? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It rises, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

Although Question 10 does not ask about the percentage of the world's nutrients provided by beef and dairy production, it does ask about the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production, which is a key part of the ground truth MCQ. The correct option for Question 10 (C. 60%) also matches the correct option for the ground truth MCQ (D. 60%, 18%). 

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as they do not ask about both the percentage of food-based emissions and the percentage of the world's nutrients provided by beef and dairy production.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A high dairy vegetarian diet produces less green house gasses than meals with modest meat portions such as chicken.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: If all meat were to be suddenly removed from our shelves, what would be the estimated reduction in food-related greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to dietitians, what type of diet is considered to contain all the necessary nutrients for a healthy life? Options: A. A diet rich in meat and fish, B. A diet consisting mainly of fruits, vegetables, and legumes, C. A diet high in dairy products, D. A diet with a balance of meat, fish, and dairy Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the initial effect on produce costs when the demand for fruits, vegetables, and legumes increases due to a lack of meat? Options: A. Costs decrease, B. Costs remain the same, C. Costs increase moderately, D. Costs soar Correct Option: D
Question 4: Which region is mentioned as having difficulty growing vegetables due to its harsh environment? Options: A. Pacific Northwest of the United States, B. Mongolia, C. Amazon rainforest, D. Africa Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the result of the meat industry collapsing in developing countries? Options: A. Many households gain income from new industries, B. Many households are left scrambling for income, C. The economy remains unaffected, D. The country becomes more prosperous Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the benefit of shifting from meat production to agricultural crops? Options: A. Increased greenhouse gas emissions, B. Higher risk of respiratory diseases, C. Workers and neighboring communities are less susceptible to respiratory diseases, D. Higher production costs Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the outcome of the increased demand for crop agriculture? Options: A. Prices increase, B. Prices remain the same, C. Prices come down, D. The demand for meat increases Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the benefits of no longer consuming meat, particularly red meat? Options: A. An increase in heart disease and cancer, B. A decrease in global biodiversity, C. Millions of deaths are avoided every year due to lower rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions, D. The risk of respiratory diseases increases Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect on global biodiversity when the pressures from agriculture subside? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It rises, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 10 is related to the topic of greenhouse gas emissions from different food sources.

However, since the ground truth MCQ specifically compares greenhouse gas emissions from a high dairy vegetarian diet to meals with modest meat portions, and none of the generated MCQs directly address this comparison, I must conclude that there is no closely matching generated MCQ.

But if I had to choose one that is somewhat related to the topic, I would say Question 10 is the closest, as it discusses the percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rosa Parks’s husband Raymond Parks was in a group that advocated for the case related to
Options: A. Emmett Till, B. The Scottsboro Boys, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In 1944, what crime was Rosa Parks investigating as an emissary for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People? Options: A. A hate crime in Montgomery, B. A vicious crime in rural Alabama involving the sexual assault of a young woman, C. A policy dispute in Detroit, D. A civil rights case in the Supreme Court Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the outcome of the initial trial of Recy Taylor's attackers, and how did Rosa Parks respond to it? Options: A. The attackers were found guilty, and Rosa Parks praised the court's decision, B. The attackers were acquitted, and Rosa Parks demanded a new trial, C. The attackers were not indicted, and Rosa Parks demanded the governor assemble a new grand jury, D. The attackers were sentenced to life in prison, and Rosa Parks felt justice had been served Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why was Rosa Parks' husband initially reluctant for her to get involved in activism? Options: A. He was afraid of losing his job as a barber, B. He was concerned about the potential dangers of activism and wanted to keep Rosa safe, C. He was opposed to the goals of the NAACP, D. He was worried about the impact on their social status Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was Rosa Parks' role in the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP, and what were her responsibilities? Options: A. She was the president of the chapter and responsible for making public speeches, B. She was the secretary of the chapter and responsible for keeping minutes, preparing public responses, and documenting civil rights cases, C. She was the treasurer of the chapter and responsible for managing finances, D. She was a general member with no specific responsibilities Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did Rosa Parks' refusal to move to the back of a segregated bus in 1955 contribute to the civil rights movement? Options: A. It sparked a wave of violent protests across the South, B. It led to a decline in NAACP membership, C. It helped ignite a grassroots movement and transform nascent civil rights activism into a national movement, D. It resulted in the immediate desegregation of public transport Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of the 381-day bus boycott that followed Rosa Parks' arrest, and what was the significance of this outcome? Options: A. The boycott ended in failure, and the civil rights movement lost momentum, B. The boycott ended with the desegregation of public transport, marking a significant victory for the civil rights movement, C. The boycott ended with the arrest of several prominent civil rights leaders, D. The boycott ended with a compromise that allowed for partial desegregation of public transport Correct Option: B
Question 7: What challenges did Rosa Parks face after her involvement in the bus boycott, and how did she respond to them? Options: A. She faced vicious death threats and was unable to find work in Montgomery, prompting her to move to Detroit and continue her activism, B. She faced opposition from within the NAACP and was forced to resign as secretary, C. She faced financial difficulties and was unable to continue her activism, D. She faced criticism from the media and was forced to go into hiding Correct Option: A
Question 8: How did Rosa Parks' activism evolve over time, and what were some of her notable achievements in her later years? Options: A. She became less involved in activism and focused on her personal life, B. She continued to work as a seamstress and abandoned her activism, C. She became more radical in her views and was involved in several high-profile protests, D. She remained active in the fight against racial inequality, writing several books, giving talks, and establishing an institute for the education of young people Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the significance of Rosa Parks' work with the NAACP youth group council, and how did it reflect her broader approach to activism? Options: A. It demonstrated her focus on working with established leaders to bring about change, B. It highlighted her commitment to empowering young people to navigate segregated systems and challenge racial inequality, C. It showed her willingness to compromise with those in power to achieve incremental gains, D. It revealed her emphasis on using violent protest as a means of achieving social change Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the central message of Rosa Parks' call to action, and how does it reflect her approach to activism? Options: A. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" suggests that activists should prioritize caution and avoid taking risks, B. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" implies that having a clear sense of purpose and conviction can overcome fear and inspire action, C. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" means that activists should focus on educating themselves about the issues rather than taking action, D. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" suggests that activists should rely on others to take the lead and make decisions Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rosa Parks famously wrote the governor on behalf of
Options: A. The Scottsboro Boys, B. Emmett Till, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In Montgomery, Rosa Parks worked as a ______ to help support her family
Options: A. A secretary, B. A seamstress, C. A librarian
Correct Option: B

Question 1: In 1944, what crime was Rosa Parks investigating as an emissary for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People? Options: A. A hate crime in Montgomery, B. A vicious crime in rural Alabama involving the sexual assault of a young woman, C. A policy dispute in Detroit, D. A civil rights case in the Supreme Court Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the outcome of the initial trial of Recy Taylor's attackers, and how did Rosa Parks respond to it? Options: A. The attackers were not indicted, and Rosa Parks demanded the governor assemble a new grand jury, D. The attackers were sentenced to life in prison, and Rosa Parks felt justice had been served Correct Option: C

She was the president of the chapter and responsible for making public speeches, B. She was the secretary of the chapter and responsible for keeping minutes, preparing public responses, and documenting civil rights cases, C. She was the treasurer of the chapter and responsible for managing finances, D. She was a general member with no specific responsibilities Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did Rosa Parks' refusal to move to the back of a segregated bus in 1955 contribute to the civil rights movement? Options: A. It sparked a wave of violent protests across the South, B. It led to a decline in NAACP membership, C. It helped ignite a grassroots movement and transform nascent civil rights activism into a national movement, D. It resulted in the immediate desegregation of public transport Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of the 381-day bus boycott that followed Rosa Parks' arrest, and what was the significance of this outcome? Options: A. The boycott ended in failure, and the civil rights movement lost momentum, B. The boycott ended with the desegregation of public transport, marking a significant victory for the civil rights movement, C. The boycott ended with the arrest of several prominent civil rights leaders, D. The boycott ended with a compromise that allowed for partial desegregation of public transport Correct Option: B
Question 7: What challenges did Rosa Parks face after her involvement in the bus boycott, and how did she respond to them? Options: A. She faced vicious death threats and was unable to find work in Montgomery, prompting her to move to Detroit and continue her activism, B. She faced opposition from within the NAACP and was forced to resign as secretary, C. She faced financial difficulties and was unable to continue her activism, D. She faced criticism from the media and was forced to go into hiding Correct Option: A
Question 8: How did Rosa Parks' activism evolve over time, and what were some of her notable achievements in her later years? Options: A. She became less involved in activism and focused on her personal life, B. She continued to work as a seamstress and abandoned her activism, C. She became more radical in her views and was involved in several high-profile protests, D. She remained active in the fight against racial inequality, writing several books, giving talks, and establishing an institute for the education of young people Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the significance of Rosa Parks' work with the NAACP youth group council, and how did it reflect her broader approach to activism? Options: A. It demonstrated her focus on working with established leaders to bring about change, B. It highlighted her commitment to empowering young people to navigate segregated systems and challenge racial inequality, C. It showed her willingness to compromise with those in power to achieve incremental gains, D. It revealed her emphasis on using violent protest as a means of achieving social change Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the central message of Rosa Parks' call to action, and how does it reflect her approach to activism? Options: A. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" suggests that activists should prioritize caution and avoid taking risks, B. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" implies that having a clear sense of purpose and conviction can overcome fear and inspire action, C. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" means that activists should focus on educating themselves about the issues rather than taking action, D. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" suggests that activists should rely on others to take the lead and make decisions Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the other woman involved in the NAACP in Montgomery?
Options: A. Elaine Steele, B. Johnnie Rebecca Carr, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: B

The attackers were not indicted, and Rosa Parks demanded the governor assemble a new grand jury, D. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" implies that having a clear sense of purpose and conviction can overcome fear and inspire action, C. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" means that activists should focus on educating themselves about the issues rather than taking action, D. "Knowing what must be done does away with fear" suggests that activists should rely on others to take the lead and make decisions Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When her family left Montgomery, Rosa Parks was hired to work in the office of
Options: A. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., B. E.D. Nixon, C. Congressman John Conyers
Correct Option: C
